text: Notice that it doesn't matter whether you, as a Methodist, approve of your neighbors' lifestyle or behavior. (Why would it?)
author: EricaGrieder

text: To elaborate: on my read, Christian sexual ethics are derived from, or a subset of,  Christian interpersonal ethics--and the religious right's preoccupation with the former is misplaced as well as misleading. (The degree to which they lean on Paul = telling!)
author: EricaGrieder

text: "Our religion does not lie in doing what God has not enjoined, or abstaining from what he hath not forbidden." (This helps explain why Methodists don't have a consensus on whether same-sex marriage, for example, is "forbidden".) (On my read, it's not. Others may disagree.)
author: EricaGrieder

text: The supporters of the Traditional Plan may prevail in St. Louis, but they've lost the debate merely by pushing this plan, in a sense. "We think and let think" is a foundational principle of the Methodist movement.
author: EricaGrieder

text:
Also good context for #UMCGC2019..."The Character of a Methodist," by John Wesley, 1742: https://www.umcmission.org/Find-Resources/John-Wesley-Sermons/The-Wesleys-and-Their-Times/The-Character-of-a-Methodist …

author: EricaGrieder

text:
With that said, @realDonaldTrump overperformed, in a sense. It pains me to admit this, but no one has ever received more votes in a statewide election in Texas than Trump did in 2016. He got 4.7m votes that year:

The top vote-getter in 2018, @GregAbbott_TX, got 4.64m votes:
author: EricaGrieder

text: For context, @realDonaldTrump carried Texas by nine points in #2016; in other words, he underperformed relative to @MittRomney, who carried the state by 16 points in 2012, and also relative to the Republicans who ran statewide in 2014, all of whom won by ~20 points.

text: 7/ I'll always respect @LupeValdez and @randrewwhite for being willing to jump on that grenade--and Lupe, it's worth noting, outperformed expectations. But ultimately I don't think Julian should be faulted for not running in 2018. He had a different plan from day one.
author: EricaGrieder

text: 6/ As a Texan, I was also looking for that in 2018. But Abbott was the least vulnerable incumbent, and the most well-resourced; his foibles are even now not as obvious to everyone as Patrick's, or Cruz's. The Dem gubernatorial nominee was almost certain to lose.
author: EricaGrieder

text: 5/ To summarize, Julian's read was that in 2020 Americans would be looking for someone with honesty and integrity, who can bring us together; who wants to create opportunity, and who represents the future.
author: EricaGrieder

text: 4/ @JulianCastro, however, wasn't considering running for anything in 2018, because he was considering a run in 2020. He was very candid about that, and yesterday said that his read on the race hasn't changed.
author: EricaGrieder

text: 3/ @JoaquinCastrotx, as has been reported, was considering the Senate race. He knew that Beto was planning to run, and rarin' to go, but that wasn't a factor in Joaquin's deliberations, because he would likely win a primary vs Beto.
author: EricaGrieder

text: 2/ As far as 2018: I met up with both Julian and Joaquin (separately) while I was in San Antonio for Christmas in December 2016, and asked them both then about their plans for 2018. (I had already talked to Beto about his.)
author: EricaGrieder
